case_name: The New Prakash Transport Co. Ltd. v. Suwarna Transport Company Limited

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 74 of 1956 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 22, 1955, of the Nagpur High Court in Letters Patent Appeal No. 2 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 74 of 1956. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 22, 1955, of the Nagpur High Court in Letters Patent Appeal No. 2 of 1955.

facts.text: The Suwarna Transport Company Limited held seven permits for running buses on the Buldana-Malkapur route as the sole operator.

anchor.surface_text: The Suwarna Transport Company Limited, which will be referred to as the first respondent in the course of this judgment, held seven permits for running buses on the Buldana-Malkapur route, as the sole operator on that route.

facts.text: Suwarna Transport Company Limited applied for another permit on the Buldana-Malkapur route.

anchor.surface_text: It applied for another permit for the same route.

facts.text: The New Prakash Transport Co. Ltd. and Navjivan Transport Service applied for a permit on the Buldana-Malkapur route.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, The New Prakash Transport Co. Ltd., as also another party, called the Navjivan Transport Service number cited in this Court  applied for a similar permit on that route.

facts.text: On May 26, 1953, the Regional Transport Authority of Amraoti heard all three applicants for the permit.

anchor.surface_text: On May 26, 1953, all the three applicants aforesaid were heard by the Regional Transport Authority of Amraoti, which is the third respondent in this Court, in connection with the permit applied for.

facts.text: Regional Transport Authority passed a resolution that no one service should have monopoly on Buldana-Malkapur route and postponed consideration.

anchor.surface_text: Consideration of the several applications was postponed, but a resolution was passed to the effect that No one service should have monopoly on Buldana-Malkapur route.

facts.text: On March 30, 1954, Regional Transport Authority granted the permit to first respondent (Suwarna).

anchor.surface_text: On March 30, 1954, another meeting of the Regional Transport Authority took place and the first respondent was granted the permit.

facts.text: Appellant's application was rejected by Regional Transport Authority on the ground that the police report was against it.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants application was rejected on the ground that the police report was against it.

facts.text: Appellant appealed to the Appellate Authority constituted under R. 73 of the Motor Vehicles Act.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant preferred an appeal to the Appellate Authority  constituted under R. 73 of the Motor -Vehicles Act , Madhya Pradesh, Nagpur, which is the second respondent to this appeal.

facts.text: Appellant challenged the correctness of the police report and applied to District Superintendent of Police to verify facts; police made a further report.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant challenged the correctness of the police report against it and applied to the District Superintendent of Police personally to verify the facts stated in the first report on the basis of which the appellants application for permit had been rejected, as aforesaid.

facts.text: Further police report was read out to parties by Chairman of Appellate Authority at the hearing; no objection raised.

anchor.surface_text: The police made a further report, which was placed before the second respondent. That further report by the police was read out to the parties by the Chairman of the Appellate Authority at the time of the hearing of the appeal. At the hearing numberobjection appears to have been raised by any of the parties

facts.text: On July 29, 1954, Appellate Authority set aside RTA order, allowed appeal, ordered permit to appellant.

anchor.surface_text: By its order dated July 29, 1954, the second respondent set aside the order of the third respondent, allowed the appeal and ordered the permit to be issued to the appellant.

facts.text: First respondent filed writ petition in Nagpur High Court under Art. 226 for certiorari on grounds of error apparent and violation of natural justice.

anchor.surface_text: The first respondent moved the High Court at Nagpur for a writ of certiorari under Art. 226 of the Constitution, substantially on two grounds, namely,  1  that the order passed by the second respondent was vitiated by an error apparent on the face of the record, and  2  that it contravened the principles of natural justice.

facts.text: Single Judge (Mr. Justice V. R. Sen) on December 13, 1954, refused writ, discharged rule.

anchor.surface_text: The petition under Arts. 226 and 227 made, as aforesaid, by the first respondent was heard by a single Judge  Mr. Justice V. R. Sen  who by his orders dated December 13, 1954, discharged the rule with costs.

facts.text: Letters Patent Appeal heard by Division Bench (Chief Justice Hidayatulla and Mr. Justice S. P. Kotwal), reversed single judge on Sep 22, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The first respondent preferred an appeal under the Letters Patent and repeated its grounds of attack against the orders of the Appellate Authority. The appeal was heard by a Division Bench consisting of Chief Justice Hidayatulla and Mr. Justice S. P. Kotwal.

facts.text: Division Bench quashed Appellate Authority order and directed rehearing.

anchor.surface_text: In the result it granted a writ quashing the order of the Appellate Authority and directing it to rehear the appeal in the light of the observations made in the course of the judgment.

facts.text: Police report dated March 27, 1954, was full of mistakes; fresh report dated May 13, 1954, absolved appellant.

anchor.surface_text: admitted that the third respondent had rejected its application on the basis of the police report dated March 27, 1954, which was full of mistakes and falsehoods, that it moved the District Superintendent of Police personally to verify the contents of the said report and that the fresh report submitted by the police after due verification had absolved the appellant

facts.text: Appellant admitted that fresh police report was read out during appeal hearing.

anchor.surface_text: The fresh report submitted by the police after verification at the appellants request was received by the second respondent and the Chairman read the same during the hearing of the appeal

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave to appeal.

anchor.surface_text: Having been unsuccessful there, the appellant came up to this Court and obtained special leave to appeal.

facts.text: Supreme Court held no failure of natural justice by Appellate Authority.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons aforesaid, in our opinion, the judgment under appeal is erroneous and must be set aside

facts.text: Second police report was based on misunderstanding and modified the first report.

anchor.surface_text: The second respondent also showed cause and corroborated the appellants statement that the first police report had been subsequently modified by the District Superintendent of Police by the report dated May 13, 1954, which showed that the previous report was based on some misunderstanding.

facts.text: No party raised objection to procedure or requested adjournment at Appellate Authority hearing.

anchor.surface_text: At the hearing no objection appears to have been raised by any of the parties to the course adopted by the second respondent.

facts.text: Regional Transport Authority is third respondent.

anchor.surface_text: Regional Transport Authority of Amraoti, which is the third respondent in this Court

facts.text: Appellate Authority read second police report to parties.

anchor.surface_text: That further report by the police was read out to the parties by the Chairman of the Appellate Authority at the time of the hearing of the appeal.

facts.text: First respondent claimed Appellate Authority misread police report and violated natural justice by not showing revised report.

anchor.surface_text: The first ground was founded on the allegation that the second respondent had misread the police report, and the second on the allegation that the revised report by the police had not been shown to the petitioner who had been afforded no real and effective opportunity

issues.text: whether or not there has been a failure of natural justice in this case as a result of the procedure adopted by the Appellate Authority

anchor.surface_text: The only question which requires determination by this Court is whether or not there has been a failure of natural justice in this case as a result of the procedure adopted by the Appellate Authority. On this question there has been a marked difference of opinion in the two stages of the case in the High Court. It has been argued on behalf of the appellant that the Appeal Bench of the Nagpur High Court has erred in coming to the conclusion that in the circumstances of this case, there has been a failure of justice,

issues.text: whether there was any error apparent on the face of the record

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the respondents it was argued that it had numberopportunity of studying the subsequent police report and of making submissions thereon with the result that there has been a failure of natural justice in the sense that the respondent had been deprived of a fair and full opportunity of being heard. Though the High Court on appeal did number base its decision on the other question, namely, whether there was any error apparent on the face of the record, it was sought to be argued that there was an error in the order of the second respondent in so far as it made reference to only the first report and read into it the maatter contained in the subsequent report.

anchor.surface_text: At the outset we may observe that, in our opinion, there is no substance in the second ground sought to be resuscitated in this Court by the learned counsel on behalf of the respondent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court Division Bench did not base decision on it; language ambiguous but consistent with second report.

holdings.text: No failure of natural justice by the Appellate Authority; reading out the subsequent police report at the hearing suffices.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Report read to parties, no objection or adjournment request; complies with statutory procedure under MV Act ss.47,48,64, r.73; no prejudice.

holdings.text: The procedure adopted by the Appellate Authority did not contravene principles of natural justice.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons aforesaid, in our opinion, the judgment under appeal is erroneous and must be set aside

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory scheme does not require providing copies or suo motu adjournments; parties heard per rules; no grievance raised at time.

holdings.text: Rules of natural justice for quasi-judicial statutory bodies like Appellate Authority are determined by the statutory scheme and vary by context; full court trial not required.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Depends on legislation; MV Act/r.73 requires hearing interested persons, further enquiry if needed; precedents (Rice, Arlidge) confirm fair hearing per statute suffices.

holdings.text: Police report to transport authorities is information/opinion for the authority's use, not evidence for parties; reading it out complies with natural justice.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Assists authority in public interest decision; not adversarial; no need to furnish copies unless statute requires.

holdings.text: Quasi-judicial tribunal not obliged to grant adjournment or provide document copies suo motu absent party request or objection.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No request by parties; cannot raise post-decision; statute allows further enquiry if deemed necessary.

holdings.text: The judgment of the Nagpur High Court Division Bench is erroneous and must be set aside; single Judge took correct view.
holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court made unjustified assumptions ignoring statutory scheme and facts (no objection); precedents support.

precedents.citation: Spackman Plumstead Board of Works 1 1885 10 A.C. 229, 240

anchor.surface_text: the case of Spackman Plumstead Board of Works 1 . In that case the question arose on a prosecution for infringement of an Act of Parliament making provision for fixing the general line of buildings in a road.

precedents.case_name: Spackman v. Plumstead Board of Works
precedents.cited_proposition: In the absence of special provisions as to how the person who is to decide is to proceed, the law will imply no more than that the substantial requirements of justice shall not be violated
precedents.cited_holding: He is not a judge in the proper sense of the word but he must give the parties an opportunity of being heard before him and stating their case and their view. He must give notice when he will proceed with the matter, and he must act honestly and impartially

anchor.surface_text: Another leading case on the subject is the decision of the House of Lords in the well-known case of Board of Education Rice 1 . Their Lordships in that case had to discuss the duty of the Board of Education under s. 7 of the Education Act, 1902.

precedents.cited_proposition: Department or officers of State deciding questions must act in good faith and fairly listen to both sides, obtain information in any way they think best, giving fair opportunity to correct prejudicial statements
precedents.cited_holding: They have no power to administer an oath, and need not examine witnesses. They can obtain information in any way they think best, always giving a fair opportunity to those who are parties in the controversy for correcting or contradicting any relevant statement prejudicial to their view.

precedents.citation: Rex v. Local Government Board, Ex parte Arlidge 1 1913 1 K.B, 463

anchor.surface_text: How far judicial opinion may vary as to the content of the rule of natural justice is amply illustrated by the case of Rex v. Local Government Board, Ex parte Arlidge 1 , at different stages.

precedents.case_name: Rex v. Local Government Board, Ex parte Arlidge
precedents.cited_proposition: Local Government Board not bound to hear appellant after inspector's report before dismissing appeal
precedents.cited_holding: The procedure indicated by the rules framed under the statute had been followed and there was no other obligation to hear the appellant

precedents.citation: Rex v. Local Government Board, Ex parte A rlidge 2 1914 1 K. B. 16o

anchor.surface_text: The matter was taken in appeal in Rex v. Local Government Board, Ex parte A rlidge 2 , and the Court of Appeal by a majority allowed the appeal holding that it was contrary to the principles of natural justice

precedents.case_name: Rex v. Local Government Board, Ex parte Arlidge
precedents.cited_proposition: Dismissal of appeal without disclosing inspector's report and opportunity to be heard contrary to natural justice
precedents.cited_holding: The non-disclosure of the inspector's report was contrary to principles of natural justice

precedents.citation: Local Government Board v. Arlidge 1 1915 A.C. 120, 132

anchor.surface_text: Against the judgment of the majority of the Court quashing the determination of the appeal by the Board there was an appeal to the House of Lords. The House of Lords unanimously adopted the opinion of Hamilton, L.J., allowed the appeal and set aside the majority decision. Vide Local Government Board v. Arlidge 1 .

precedents.cited_proposition: Statutory tribunals must act judicially but procedure need not be the same as courts; obey the statute
precedents.cited_holding: The assumption that the methods of natural justice are ex necessitate those of Courts of justice is wholly unfounded

precedents.citation: General Medical Council v. Spackman 1 1943 A.C. 827

anchor.surface_text: Another recent decision of the House of Lords in the case of General Medical Council v. Spackman 1 was relied upon by the High Court in the judgment under appeal.

precedents.cited_proposition: Tribunal must satisfy statutory requirements for due inquiry; rules of natural justice inferred from statute and rules
precedents.cited_holding: The Council was bound to satisfy the requirements of the law and the rules made thereunder; must examine witnesses if tendered

precedents.citation: R. v. Architects Registration Tribunal 1 1945 2 A.E.R. 131

anchor.surface_text: To that class belongs the case of R. v. Architects Registration Tribunal 1 . In that case the Kings Bench Division issued an order of certiorari to quash the tribunals decision refusing an application for registration as an architect.

precedents.cited_proposition: Tribunal cannot act on adverse report without giving opportunity to meet allegations on fitness for profession

precedents.citation: Leeson v. General Council of Medical Education and Registration 1 1890 43 Ch. D. 366

anchor.surface_text: The cases of Leeson v. General Council of Medical Education and Registration 1 , and Allinson v. General Council of Medical Education and Registration 2 also belong to that category.

precedents.case_name: Leeson v. General Council of Medical Education and Registration
precedents.cited_proposition: Medical Council must give full opportunity to person proceeded against in cases of striking off for unprofessional conduct

precedents.citation: Allinson v. General Council of Medical Education and Registration 2 1894 1 Q.B. 750

anchor.surface_text: The cases of Leeson v. General Council of Medical Education and Registration 1 , and Allinson v. General Council of Medical Education and Registration 2 also belong to that category.

precedents.case_name: Allinson v. General Council of Medical Education and Registration
precedents.cited_proposition: Medical Council must give full opportunity to person proceeded against in cases of striking off for unprofessional conduct

precedents.citation: R. v. Archbishop of Canterbury 3 1944 1 A.E.R. 179

anchor.surface_text: Another class of cases is illustrated by the decision of the Court of Appeal in R. v. Archbishop of Canterbury 3 . In that case the Archbishop of Canterbury reviewing the order of the Bishop refused to approve the clerk

precedents.cited_proposition: Not all decisions involving property rights require quasi-judicial procedure unless statute provides
precedents.cited_holding: There was no justification for regarding the matter as lis inter partes; no quasi-judicial enquiry required

precedents.citation: Veerappa Pillai v. Raman Raman Ltd. 1 1952 S. C. R. 583

anchor.surface_text: The provisions of the Act were examined in detail by a Bench of five Judges of this Court in the case of Veerappa Pillai v. Raman Raman Ltd. 1 . This Court examined elaborately the provisions of the Act vis-a-vis the authorities

precedents.case_name: Veerappa Pillai v. Raman & Raman Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: Complete scheme in Motor Vehicles Act for permits; remedies within statute; High Court interference limited
precedents.cited_holding: Thus we have before us a complete and precise scheme for regulating the issue of permits, providing what matters are to be taken into consideration as relevant, and prescribing appeals and revisions from subordinate bodies to higher authorities.
